Posts.Content: Hi all,  I'd love some advice about what to do after I have my mastectomy. After being diagnosed mid December, and having multiple biopsies, my lymph glands are clear! Hurray!  I now need to be 100% sure which surgery I'm going to go with. I can have my mastectomy and full deip/from my back reconstruction, or, have an expander implant and then later have my reconstruction. The risk of having a big op is longer recovery and waiting time if I need chemo or rads. Also if I do have rads it could damage the new breast. Posts.Title: Side effects of tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Hi all, I really need the mother of all rants and this is the safest place to do it. So that it's off my chest and out in the world.  I had my last chemo over a week ago. I thought I'd be cartwheeling down the street and feeling on top of the world! But no, quite the opposite. I feel real anger, and it's at everything. But particularly at the moment it's at a recent stay in hospital. I went in with a high temp, sore throat, bad chest. It's the second time this has happened to me. I hated the first and wanted to do anything to avoid it. But I knew I had to. They gave fluids and antibiotics and because I had to have those horrid injections to boost my white cell count, I needed co codamol for the pain. But with co codamol brings constipation. So I asked for some laxatives. Sure we just need to get a doc to prescribe it. Okay, then nothing. Ask again and again and again. So today I was doubled up in the ward toilet having the worst time. My bottom was in a right state and me in agony. If they had just listened and gave me what I needed I would have been much better. I could have looked after myself better at home. I'm home tonight and have endured another really painful experience. The same thing happened with cough medicine for some relief while swallowing. Asked for it three times before I was given some. Normally here I'd defend the staff and say how great they were, and its underfunding. But it felt like it was lack of care. One nurse tried to take blood from a vein in my thumb, as soon as the needle went in it was painful, so I asked her to remove it politely, she continued to jab it around until I cried out in pain. I knew where she would find a vein, but she ignored me. The next nurse did it straight away. I'm angry I've had chemo, I'm angry that I didn't do what I wanted to and to be swayed by stats and talk of an investment in my future. I will never know if chemo has made any difference to my life. This drop in the ocean of time  is rubbish. It's leaving a big black hole of hurt on my life. I feel battered and brow beaten. And not just because of the above, but because of all of it. I understand chemo saves lives and I'm not undervaluing it or the people who work for the NHS. But in my heart of hearts now I know I didn't need chemo. And I'm angry at the professionals that talked me into it.  I hope with time my anger fades and I don't end up a bitter old woman with one boob and a story to tell. I hate cancer, I read an article today with the depressing title that more people will get cancer than get married. If I thought it was an either or situation I'd have got married long ago. It basically says that cancer has become one of those inevitable milestones in life.... If you've got this far, thanks for reading!  And good luck on your cancer journey Kerry xx www.google.co.uk/.../cancer-common-marriage-wake-up-call-macmillan

Posts.Content: Thank you to all you lovely ladies for reading and replying. It's good to share with people who understand.  ❤️
Posts.Title: Big old rant!

Posts.Content: Hi Amanda, This was just my experience when I had my mastectomy and this is not to freak you out. I wasn't bothered at all, it was just a very surreal moment. But when I went in for my op, I was ushered into what can only be described as a broom cupboard of a room, with my mum and sister and about 8 staff. Including my breast consultant, a couple of plastic surgeons the anesthetist etc. I had to take my top part off while I was drawn on by a couple of people, and while they discussed my op. If felt really clinical and practical and that basically I was a bit of meat. But on reflection it was good, because when I thought about it after, they had pulled everyone together so they would all hear exactly the same information. Everyone was clear for example which breast was being removed.......v important I'm not going to lie, it felt a bit awkward, it was 7:30am and I was a bit dazed standing topless in a cupboard. But they did an amazing job, they saved my life and gave me a new breast. They knew their stuff. But I couldn't help but notice the vast difference between my breast consultant and plastic surgeons approach. The consultant was tactile, he gave me privacy to undress and a sheet to cover up with. My plastic surgeon didn't do any of that. I think he led the broom cupboard pre op meeting. To be honest by that point I felt like everyone had seen my boobs anyway! The hospital staff have seen it all, and if you don't feel comfortable just say. If your concerned about being covered up, make that clear. Try not to get too worried about it and good luck with your operation. Kerry xxxx

Posts.Content: Hi Mimi, I know how you’re feeling. I had my last chemo 4th Sept. I was always worried right before but I was also desperate to get it over with. Getting to the halfway point is a great feeling, knowing that you’re at the top of the mountain and the rest is the descent. Before chemo needles didn’t phase me at all, but I really hate them now. I wish I’d had a picc line put in, so if you’re concerned about your veins maybe this would suit you.  You’re right the nurse shouldn’t have taken your blood pressure on your surgery side. I think it has something to do with the lymph nodes???? I had a nurse take blood from my surgery side despite me telling her, my veins were a bit rubbish from chemo so I think she decided just to do it in the other arm. I realised after I should’ve insisted, but you assume they know best. Sometimes it does feel overwhelming and scary but you will be finished really soon. My advice is never worry about speaking up, if something feels odd or is difficult or painful just say.  Sending you lots of good luck for the rest of your treatment, you’re doing great and it will be over soon. Posts.Content: Hi Judy, I've only just seen this, and I think you're right. When I saw that advert it didn't sit right, but mainly I was thinking  why would anyone willingly do that to themselves. I would never ask or want anyone to lose their hair. Isn't it funny those of us who have been through it probably wouldn't wish it in their worst enemy. However our loved ones see it as a token of solidarity. I think you're right to start this discussion, and I do hope Macmillan listen. Losing my hair, eyebrows and eyelashes has been a really awful experience. Trying to get on with wearing a wig, false lashes and drawn on eyebrows, has left me looking at a sad stranger in the mirror. To be honest, I actually feel better going out without. If people stare, I'd rather they stared at my bald head and not half an eyelash falling off or a ill fitting wig. But I do have to mention that I do love the 'life with cancer is still a life' campaign. It is very poignant for me at the moment, as I'm having chemo as a preventative treatment. Each round I want to give up because I have nothing to measure it by. I feel I have no quality of life. It reminds me to keep on living my life and not hide away. But I also feel like our loved ones are living with it too, so it kind of relates to them too. I guess it's trial and error, they can't get it right all of the time. But it's important to discuss it openly and not worry about criticising it just because the intention was good. Kerry x
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Hi Welshi, I've just had a mastectomy with abdomen recon one week ago. I have a bmi of 38. When I discussed it with the plastic surgeon he said I was a good candidate but wanted the anesthetist to see me and talk about the risks of being sedated 8 to 10 hrs. My consultant who did the mastectomy said he would support whichever treatment I wanted. He described it as the royals Royce treatment, it came at a higher price, but when it worked it worked really well. I just needed to go into it with my eyes wide open. Other than my weight I'm generally fit and healthy so she had no issue with it. My surgery went well and no complications. Obviously I'm not out of the woods but I'm up and about, moving around. I guess my only thing really is the extra weight makes mobility harder after surgery. E.g. Getting out of bed. The first time I moved from bed to chair I thought I was going to be sick! And moving back I had a little cry.  However, I'm glad I did it in one go, the thought of facing another big op down the line didn't appeal to me.  I've never had a c section so I'm not sure what that conversation would be. But I'm sure it's considered on an individual by individual basis. Good luck xx

Posts.Title: Your cancer wasn't bad then....

Posts.Content: Hi Clare, It took five weeks to get my test results back but it originally was supposed to be  two. I actually had an appointment with the oncologist at four weeks, only to be told they didn't have the result. I was really upset because I was really hoping for a low score and had got myself all worked up. I had several small areas of invasive bc, the largest of which was 5mm grade 3 no lymph node involvement er positive, her2 negative. My test results came back as 20, and I was advised to have chemo unfortunately. I think it was maybe down to the grade and my age too (I'm 38). It's like an insurance policy for the future, but I will really never know if it's going to pay off. But even before I was offered the test, my consultant had said he thought I should have Chemo. So if you were told that you probably wouldn't gain much from having it in the first place, the oncotype test will probably say the same. I think this test is excellent, and I'm sure it's reduced the number of people who have chemo. I can imagine there were a lot of people having treatment that probably didn't need to. Good luck Clare, I'm hoping you get a nice low result. Kerry x
